questions.question_text: You must use different Terraform commands depending on the cloud provider you use.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B. False
the commands to use to interact with Terraform itself (such as terraform apply, terraform plan, and so on) remain the same regardless of the cloud provider.

questions.question_text: Define the purpose of state in Terraform.

choices.C: State codifies the dependencies of related resources
choices.A: State stores variables and lets you quickly reuse existing code
choices.D: State maps real world resources to your configuration and keeps track of metadata
choices.B: State lets you enforce resource configurations that relate to compliance policies

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
keeps track of metadata is the key word regarding state file

Selected Answer: C
will prevent to change something in state file means state locking is the correct answer so option C is the correct answer

Selected Answer: C
"If supported by your backend, Terraform will lock your state for all operations that could write state. This prevents others from acquiring the lock and potentially corrupting your state."
https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/language/state/locking

choices.A: Refresh the state after running Terraform
choices.C: Configure state locking for your state backend
choices.D: Run Terraform with parallelism set to 1
choices.B: Delete the state before running Terraform

questions.question_text: Which of these actions will prevent two Terraform runs from changing the same state file at the same time?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Be very careful with this command. If you unlock the state when someone else is holding the lock it could cause multiple writers. Force unlock should only be used to unlock your own lock in the situation where automatic unlocking failed.
Source: https://www.terraform.io/language/state/locking

Selected Answer: C
The force-unlock command should be used when you need to manually release a Terraform state lock that cannot be released by other means. This command is typically used in scenarios where a Terraform command was interrupted, and the lock was not released automatically. Using the force-unlock command will forcibly release the lock, but it may leave the Terraform state in an inconsistent state, so it should be used with caution.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

C. Automatic unlocking failed

Selected Answer: C
C for sure

Selected Answer: C
C. Automatic unlocking failed

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

Selected Answer: C
C. Force unlock should not be used under normal circumstances

Selected Answer: C
answer is c

Selected Answer: C
C is correct answer.
https://www.terraform.io/language/state/locking
https://www.terraform.io/cli/commands/force-unlock

questions.question_text: When should you use the force-unlock command?

choices.B: You have a high priority change
choices.D: You apply failed due to a state lock
choices.A: You see a status message that you cannot acquire the lock

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
"You can set TF_LOG to one of the log levels (in order of decreasing verbosity) TRACE, DEBUG, INFO, WARN or ERROR to change the verbosity of the logs."
https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/internals/debugging
